Ricky Bobby.Action: Runs up to Reese and hugs him upon his arrival.
Tells the class his father is not present, mother says he is off getting speeding tickets and chasing tail.
Shows lack of awareness about why the class laughs at his comment about his father; appears socially awkward and unaware of social cues.
Runs up and hugs his father Reese enthusiastically, showing emotional confidence and openness in a difficult family situation.
Watches quietly as his father is forcibly removed from school without intervening
Expresses awe and pride repeating father’s mantra 'If you ain't first, you’re last'
Beans with pride when introduced as a race car driver by his father.
Listens to his father's confident, albeit misguided, advice about speed and winning.
Does not intervene or correct his father's disruptive behavior in school.
Raises his hand to volunteer to drive after the previous driver dies, expressing eagerness to go fast.
Acknowledges Lucius’s concern but asserts his own capability and decides to take control driving the car aggressively and skillfully.
Taps another car's fender then expertly dodges wreckage during the race.
Appears extremely nervous during an interview after finishing third.
Apologizes softly for not finishing first, expressing a desire to improve for his father's sake.
Throws a balled up piece of paper with a taunting message into Cal Naughton’s car after winning.
Speaks nervously and incoherently during a media interview, showing lack of confidence and poor communication skills.
Drives skillfully and aggressively through three cars near the finish line to win a race, demonstrating driving talent and confidence.
Throws a balled up piece of paper at a competitor's car after winning, showing childishness and lack of professionalism.
Does victory donuts and writes 'I'm #1' in the turf, celebrating with fans enthusiastically.
Line dances with a dozen, then a hundred people, showing friendly engagement.
After spinning out and failing, stands on hood to wave two American flags to fans who cheer him despite failure.
Tries risky move between two cars leading to crash, showing recklessness but also a drive to please crowd.
Locks eyes with a hot drunk blonde flashing him at the race, reaction unmentioned.
Carries Carley in wedding gown into new house and they make out furiously
Works with crew members on engine, shares product endorsement with enthusiasm
Leads and dances with large crowd at country western bar
Speaks rapidly and enthusiastically about his love for racing during multiple interviews
Winning multiple races and celebrating victory in Victory Lane with crew and crowd.
Working actively on his engine with crew members.
Featuring in multiple TV interviews where he communicates enthusiastically about racing.
Describing his feelings during the interview in a disjointed, awkward manner ('I feel alike a fat man who... wrecked into the cookie dough truck').
Chuckles warmly and engages in light-hearted interaction on talk shows.
Gives a wink and a click after stating 'If you ain’t first, you’re last.' to reporters.
Sits at the head of the dinner table holding hands with family to say grace.
Confidently states 'If you aint first, you're last' to hundreds of reporters, showing self-assurance and a clear, decisive mindset.
Appears on multiple talk shows, including Spanish language and family-friendly shows, and engages with diverse audiences, indicating social adaptability and media savvy.
Presents a consistent, simple personal motto rather than nuanced strategy, which might limit deeper understanding or flexibility.
Prays in a humorous and somewhat self-centered manner, boasting about his wins and earnings during grace.
Shows confidence in his racing ability by stating 'I'm the one who wins races and I'm the one who gets money!!!'
Appears somewhat unaware or dismissive of social norms by repeatedly calling Jesus 'Baby Jesus' despite corrections.
Defends his sons’ disrespectful behavior toward their grandfather and encourages them by calling them winners who can do whatever they want.
Pays for family expenses including food and leg treatments, recognized by Carley.
Greets fans warmly, signs autographs on various surfaces including faces and even a baby.
Expresses disdain for rival driver Jean Grard and derogatorily comments on their cars.
Apologizes to Susan for the autograph situation and tries to be considerate.
Ignores advice from spotter Lucius to settle for fourth place; insists on competing aggressively.
Apologizes quickly for potentially getting someone in trouble in autograph mode, showing social awareness but slight nervousness.
Checks with Stephen to confirm ticket availability for a special guest, showing diligence and preparation.
Refuses to settle for fourth place and tries to pass through a very small gap between two cars, demonstrating confidence and willingness to take calculated risks.
Does not heed his spotter's advice to stay in his lane and attempts a risky maneuver, which could be seen as either bold or reckless.
Flips Cal the bird after winning the race.
Joins crew in celebrating the win enthusiastically.
Accelerates toward a very small gap between two cars, causing a multi-car spin out and clearing the way for Cal Naughton.
Upon spinning out, quickly recovers by driving his car in reverse, passing Cal, and winning the race.
Flips Cal Naughton off after winning the race.
Celebrates confidently and claims winning is 'just called driving,' showing self-assurance.
Dismisses serious warnings about risks of racing and mortality with lighthearted remarks on living centuries, showing possible lack of seriousness about dangers.
Tells a crew member to stop hunping the car, expressing disapproval of inappropriate behavior.
Makes a sarcastic and insulting comment to team owner about his surgery.
Defends his right to speak freely, showing confidence but also disregard for authority.
Corrects crew member Kyle for inappropriate behavior during celebration to maintain professionalism.
Disrespects team owner by making a sarcastic and insulting comment about his surgery.
Maintains confidence when confronted by the team owner and asserts his right to free speech.
Yells enthusiastic praise to Keith, engages playfully with bartender and friends
Apologizes sincerely to Cal after being warned
Throws a bottle at the jukebox to stop jazz music, showing intolerance
Insults Jean Girard for being French and attempts to punch him.
Reluctantly agrees to say 'I love crepes' after being put in a painful hold, showing humor and acceptance.
Refuses to say 'I love crepes' due to pride, insists on having his arm broken instead.
Friends and fellow drivers come to aid him after his arm is broken.
Refuses to say 'I love crepes' despite pressure and pain, choosing pride over a simple statement.
Demonstrates determination and commitment to his decision even when it results in physical harm.
Engages in a stubborn act that leads to self-injury and does not resolve the situation effectively.
Threatens M. Fancypants with a knife and aggressive language.
Expresses confusion and appears vulnerable by fainting when confronted with unexpected information.
Acknowledges being challenged by Jean Girard breaking his track record and reacts with urgency, running to the pit row immediately.
Despite being under pressure, maintains awareness of his competition and track progress, showing focus and competitive mindset.
Responds defensively and emotionally to Cal Naughton's taunt by telling him to shut up.
Sarcastically insults Jean when he tries to sign his cast ('Why don’t you sign my balls') and knocks over a tool drawer in frustration
Yells at his crew to get his car off the trailer and insists on driving despite his injured arm
Refuses to accept advice calmly, demands immediate action with aggressive tone
Reassures Susan he will be okay despite injury and tries to calm her worries.
Allows Carley to speak harshly to Susan without intervening or defending her.
Decides to race despite a broken arm, showing determination and confidence.
Sawing off his own cast methodically, showing resourcefulness and self-reliance.
Assures Susan he can see adequately by hunching down, demonstrating confidence but possibly underestimating risk.
Allows a giant Fig Newton sticker on his windshield potentially impairing visibility, which could be dangerous.
Carley kisses Ricky and he winces in pain but reassures her it's alright.
Ducks down to see under the product sticker on his windshield despite poor visibility.
Asks his spotter for information about what is going on ahead since he can't see.
Ignites competitive spirit by persistently trying to pass Grard despite obstacles and warnings
Mocks Jean Grard ('WII! hello Frenchie...')
Ignores NASCAR's black flag (mandatory pit stop) to maintain position
Panics uncontrollably after his crash, screaming and begging for help from various religious figures and motivational speakers.
Panics uncontrollably after a severe crash, screaming irrationally and failing to remain calm despite reassurance from rescue workers.
Survives a dangerous crash that rolls the car multiple times and explodes, indicating physical resilience and some level of driving skill to have gotten into the race and been competitive.
Appears catatonic and unable to respond to trauma, showing mental shutdown rather than active coping.
Passive and hazy POV experiences, no demonstrated skilled or confident behavior in the hospital scenes.
Jokes about being dead and meeting Bruce Lee while in a vulnerable hospital state
Plays wheelchair basketball aggressively, slamming into others and ripping the ball away
Acknowledges visitors when called, showing social engagement
Jokes about possibly being dead and wanting to meet Bruce Lee despite looking severely injured; shows humor and presence of mind.
Aggressively plays wheelchair basketball, uses physical skill and competitive spirit despite his injury.
Falls out of the wheelchair and crawls back, showing determination to keep up with others.
Feigns paralysis to others, suggesting strategic manipulation of the situation.
Does not initially reveal his ability to use his legs, possibly causing misunderstanding among peers.
Expresses deep vulnerability about his injury and future, showing his emotional pain openly.
Curses at and harshly rebukes Lucius and Mr. Dennit for telling him he can walk, showing anger and blaming others.
Expresses empathy in a twisted way by cursing others to experience pain similar to his own.
Attempts self-harm out of despair.
Gives up physical therapy and resigns himself to being handicapped, displaying a lack of perseverance and acceptance of defeat.
Buys a handicapped accessible van and installs ramps and stair elevator in his house, demonstrating practical and forward-thinking behavior in adjusting to his condition.
Refuses to accept that he can walk and reacts with anger and self-pity, showing emotional instability and poor adaptability.
Stabs his own leg in a moment of despair, displaying irrational and self-destructive behavior.
Sincerely apologizes and expresses hope that others are okay ('I’m sorry and I don’t hope your boys lose their legs')
Shows insecurity regarding his ability after injury and the rise of a competitor (asks Lucius how good Frenchie is, downplays his own ability)
Jumps out of the chair screaming in pain after stabbing his leg with a knife.
Dismisses his injury as the reason for losing a race and expresses confidence he can beat anyone despite his arm injury.
Seeks information about his competition and tries to assess the situation after being away from racing.
Gives a thumbs up to supporters and encourages the team with positive energy ('The Big Dog’s ready to run y’all.')
Shows consideration by asking if he is making others nervous while testing the car
Displays enthusiasm and joy upon returning to racing ('I missed you Mara Speed!!! Woo!!')
Does not interact directly with reporters or others beyond a basic thumbs up, limited verbal communication
Expresses excitement and enjoyment while pushing the limits of the car’s speed.
Inquires anxiously whether he’s on fire, showing vulnerability and concern.
Accepts Mr. Dennit’s advice on taking a break calmly and without resistance.
Attempts to push the car to high speeds but shows misunderstanding of the car's actual performance (thinks he's going 180-200 mph but is only going 35 mph).
Acknowledges that he has lost nerve and needs a break after the attempt.
After the incident, quietly accepts the decision to deactivate the car temporarily.
Appears breathless and confused about what just happened, indicating a lack of situational awareness or emotional control under pressure.
Allows his children to have cake icing for breakfast and run the lawn mower over a phone book, showing permissiveness and playfulness
Drives slowly and cautiously with hazards on during rain, putting family safety first
Returns to his childhood home with his children, knocking on his mother's door, showing vulnerability and trust
Admits to his mother 'I got nowhere to go...' expressing sincerity and openness about his struggles
Drives very slowly and tentatively with hazards on, letting other cars pass him on the highway.
Knocks on his mother's door with luggage and sons in tow, admitting he has nowhere to go.
Responds to his son's playful requests with a casual 'I guess so,' showing a relaxed attitude toward parenting.
Pulls over willingly for police after traffic violation
Promises officer the violation won't happen again despite evident stress
Carelessly causes minor accidents (ripping off fender, hitting shopping cart) while driving nervously
Hands over his license to the police officer without argument.
Attempts to explain to a passenger on the bus why he is delivering pizzas.
Ricky gets defensive and dismissive toward the passenger who says 'I don’t really care.'
Engages briefly in a somewhat friendly exchange with Cal Naughton Jr. despite their mutual dislike.
Shows honesty when he admits he did not know about Cal and Carley.
Walks away from Cal after being called a coward, avoiding conflict escalation.
Backs into the police officer, knocking him into the air; hands over his license slowly.
Delivers pizzas by bus and rides a kid's bike to his house, implying adaptation to his circumstances.
Refuses to return to racing despite encouragement and challenge from Cal Naughton Jr., citing lack of license and loss of confidence.
Sheepishly walks back to the house after being insulted by Cal, appearing broken and vulnerable.

Considers the race and legacy seriously, shows vulnerability in silence after his father insists on unfinished business.
Eventually agrees to race again but refuses to call his father 'Dad'.

Reluctantly agrees to race again and listen to his father’s help, showing openness to improvement.
Avoids acknowledging his father as 'Dad' indicating emotional resistance but still proceeds to accept help.
Punches his Dad in the jaw when confronted with unresolved anger.
Tries to understand his Dad’s lesson about driving with fear despite anger and fear.
Refuses initially to get back in the car with a cougar, showing fear and distrust.

Jogging over to intervene while Lucy disciplines the children.

Enters looking disheveled and expresses frustration about wasting his time dealing with a 'crazy dirtbag'.
Responds calmly and jogs over to assist when Lucy intervenes with the children.
Follows his dad's unusual instruction to go extremely slow to overcome fear; demonstrates patience and trust in his father's guidance.
Still attempts the slow lap despite confusion and challenge, showing sincerity and willingness to improve.
Follows his father's instruction to drive very slowly around the track to overcome fear, showing willingness to learn and patience.
Struggles initially with the concept of driving slowly to conquer fear, indicating confusion but ultimately complies.
Attempts to drive blindfolded to prove a point, shows willingness to try despite risk.
Reacts with frustration when his dad throws water on him and disrupts his rest.
Attempts to drive blindfolded, trying to trust his instincts instead of his eyes.
Crashes repeatedly while driving blindfolded, causing damage and ultimately crashing into a house.
Remembers and correctly identifies the origin of stock car racing (rumrunners during Prohibition).
Argues with his dad and calls him 'sick crazy old-' but immediately takes action to escape the cops to protect himself.
Drives skillfully and confidently to evade police pursuit, including driving at 160 mph and making a U-turn on the freeway to escape.
Trusts his instincts and reacts quickly under pressure when faced with imminent arrest.

Stops and gives his BMX bike to a kid on the curb.

Internalizes and regrets following his father’s reckless advice
Attempts to calm the situation while Reese Bobby is being thrown out, shows persistence chasing after his father to understand or help him.

Engages emotionally with his father despite the dysfunctional behavior, demonstrating interpersonal awareness and emotional intelligence.

Jokes affectionately with Lucius, offers a playful compliment, and shares a friendly hug.

Expresses that he missed his team, including Glenn, and hopes to get Carley back so everything will be perfect.

Reassembles a new team and secures sponsors despite their low profile, showing determination and resourcefulness.
Acknowledges the low-end sponsors but remains optimistic about racing and focused on Victory Lane.

Shows friendly curiosity by engaging with Jean G. Rard and the models, asking questions clearly and casually.
Responds respectfully to Jean G. Rard's challenge and acknowledges the competition in a lighthearted manner.

Panics but follows instructions and tries hard to say the French command correctly to stop the attacking dogs.
Turns off negative TV broadcast to protect his sons from harsh criticism
Encourages his sons to be proud of him regardless of the race outcome

Returns to racing after a six-month absence, determined to give his all on the track.
Turns off the TV after hearing negative commentary about his abilities and prospects.
Shows confidence and encouragement to his sons before the race.
Despite being called 'tragic and emotionally damaged' by commentators, continues forward.
Expresses appreciation to his exhausted team for working all night on the engine.
Makes an awkward and somewhat inappropriate joke comparing the engine to looking up Pam Anderson's skirt, causing crew discomfort.
Shows optimistic and friendly behavior by warmly greeting Carley and expressing eagerness to reconnect after hearing John Daly is gone.
Appreciates and acknowledges the hard work of his exhausted team who worked all night on the engine.
Examines the engine confidently and enthusiastically with positive remarks about its quality.
Makes an awkward and somewhat inappropriate analogy about the engine to Pam Anderson's skirt, which the crew finds uncomfortable.
Responds to Carley’s information about John Daly abruptly and naively assumes they will get back together again, showing a lack of social or emotional awareness.
Focuses on the race, controls emotions to perform; prepares mentally before driving.
Struggles with emotional vulnerability momentarily before the race starts.
Greets fans warmly on camera and sends shout-outs to his sons, Hank and Williams Jr.
Admits nerves and apologizes to his crew chief Lucius for being distracted during the race.
Looks away from the road to the camera while driving, risking safety despite being warned.

Successfully moves up from 26th to 12th place during the race.
Makes a big move in the race, advancing from twelfth place to third.
Communicates efficiently during the race by telling Lucius to put Cal Naughton through to talk.

Refuses to cheat by not deliberately causing another driver to crash, even when pressured and offered personal incentives.

Shows hesitation and confusion asking what to do in the moment, needing external guidance.
Shows sportsmanlike attitude by expressing that he almost doesn't care who won, emphasizing the experience over victory.

Responds appreciatively to Carley flashing him, distracted and praises her in a friendly, sincere manner.

Gets distracted by Carley flashing him mid-race, causing loss of control and a crash.
Effectively escapes the wrecked car despite injuries, showing presence of mind and basic survival competence.
Responds to Lucy's encouragement and pushes himself to finish the race on foot despite being exhausted and bloodied.
Despite physical exhaustion and uncertainty, he pushes himself to run on foot to the finish line and wins the race.
Looks to his pit crew for guidance in a crucial moment but instead finds encouragement from Lucy, showing reliance on others for direction in a high-pressure situation.

Reese Bobby.Action: Peeks into the classroom smoking a cigarette, hands Ricky five dollars after apologizing for absence.

Ricky Bobby.Action: Refuses to accept the new teammate Jean Girard and verbally dismisses the decision, showing resistance to change and poor judgment.
Stops looking at his superior when told to, defying authority with a confident but disrespectful attitude.

Expresses vulnerability by almost crying and openly sharing his emotions.
